title: As a student, should I write a thank you email to my teacher? - Quora

response.answer_text: I was 11 and, from a class of some 40 pupils, I and 5 of my fellow pupils had been selected to go to the Grammar School. This was a big, life transforming opportunity for all of us. Our teacher, Mr Leitch, was a lovely, kind, generous man to whom we all owed a debt of gratitude. My Mum said, “What are you all doing to thank him?” The answer was, nothing. I felt ashamed. So, that night, the evening before our last day at school, my Dad took me around to the house of Stan, another of the “Boteler Boys” (the name of the school we had been accepted into) and we agreed to get some fancy stationery as a gift for Mr Leitch together with a card, which we would get all the other lads to sign. At the end of our last ever day at that school, the whole class tearfully said goodbye to this wonderful teacher and “The Boteler Boys” duly handed over our gift to him. He was gracious, embarrassed and kind. Why do I still remember it and him nearly 50 years later? Because a good, kind teacher is so precious and we were so lucky to have had him. Thank them from the bottom of your heart.

Only if you wish to both demonstrate the human quality commonly known as “gratitude” and to avoid the shortcoming often labelled being a “douche.” Otherwise, why waste the seventeen seconds that could easily take? If you are interested in being a decent human being—or even an outstanding one— you might even double-down and put pen to paper, fashioning a handwritten artifact documenting that gratitude and non-douchiness. Imagine the positive and lasting impact of such a “kind” gesture!

You might consider actually writing a paper note or physical thank you card or letter. It shows a little more effort and caring. These are the REAL paychecks of teaching, knowing that you have touched and affected the heart as well as the mind of your students.
